metadata.title: Yellen v. Confederated Tribes of the Chehalis Reservation
metadata.caseName: Janet L. Yellen, Secretary of the Treasury v. Confederated Tribes of the Chehalis Reservation, et al.

court.name: Supreme Court of the United States

section.heading: Factual background
section.p: For over a century after the Alaska Purchase in 1867, the federal government had no settled policy on recognition of Alaska Native groups as Indian tribes. In 1971, Congress enacted the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act (ANCSA), which authorized the creation of two types of corporations to receive money and land: Alaska Native Regional Corporations and Alaska Native Village Corporations (collectively ANCs).

In 1975, Congress enacted the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act (ISDA) to “help Indian tribes assume responsibility for aid programs that benefit their members.” ISDA defines an “Indian tribe” as “any Indian tribe, band, nation, or other organized group or community, including any Alaska Native village or regional or village corporation as defined in or established pursuant to the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act (85 Stat. 688), which is recognized as eligible for the special programs and services provided by the United States to Indians because of their status as Indians.”

In 2020, Congress passed the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (CARES Act), Title V of which makes certain funds available to the recognized governing bodies of any "Indian Tribe" as that term is defined in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act (ISDA). The Department of the Treasury concluded that ANCs were eligible to receive Title V funds.

Six federally recognized tribes in Alaska and twelve federally recognized tribes in the lower 48 states challenged that determination, arguing that ANCs are not “Indian Tribes” within the meaning of the CARES Act or ISDA. Although the government conceded that ANCs have not been historically recognized as eligible for special programs and services because of their status as Indians, it nevertheless argued that Congress expressly included ANCs within the ISDA definition.

The district court granted summary judgment to the defendants, finding that ANCs must qualify as Indian tribes to give effect to their express inclusion in the ISDA definition, even though no ANC has been recognized as an Indian tribe. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia reversed, holding that ANCs are not eligible for funding under Title V of the CARES Act because they are not “recognized” as Indian tribes.

section.heading: Questions Presented
section.p: Are Alaska Native regional and village corporations established pursuant to the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act “Indian Tribes” for purposes of the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act?

section.heading: Holding / Conclusion
section.p: Alaska Native Corporations (ANCs) are “Indian tribe[s]” under the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act (ISDA) and thus eligible for funding available to “Tribal governments” under Title V of the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act. Justice Sonia Sotomayor authored the 5-4 majority opinion of the Court.

The majority determined that under the plain meaning of the ISDA, ANCs are Indian tribes. The Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act (ANCSA) is the only statute the ISDA’s “Indian tribe” definition mentions by name, so eligibility for ANCSA’s benefits satisfies the definition’s final “recognized-as-eligible” clause. The respondents failed to demonstrate that the phrase “Indian tribe” is a term of art that should exclude ANCs, and none of their other arguments for reading “Indian tribes” as exclusive of ANCs were persuasive.

Justice Neil Gorsuch authored a dissenting opinion, joined by Justices Clarence Thomas and Elena Kagan. Justice Gorsuch argued that the plain language and construction of the ISDA suggest that ANCs are not “Indian tribes,” supported by analogy to another statute with “nearly identical language in remarkably similar contexts,” and that the majority overlooked the critical statutory word “recognized.”

section.heading: Decision
section.p: Alaska Native Corporations are “Indian tribe[s]” under the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act and thus eligible for funding available to “Tribal governments” under Title V of the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act.

Pair.Question: What is the precise definition of an "Indian tribe" provided within the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act (ISDA), which was central to the CARES Act funding dispute?
Pair.Answer: ISDA defines an “Indian tribe” as “any Indian tribe, band, nation, or other organized group or community, including any Alaska Native village or regional or village corporation as defined in or established pursuant to the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act (85 Stat. 688), which is recognized as eligible for the special programs and services provided by the United States to Indians because of their status as Indians”.

Pair.Question: What was the specific statutory argument used by the majority to conclude that Alaska Native Corporations (ANCs) satisfy the "recognized-as-eligible" clause of the ISDA definition?
Pair.Answer: The majority determined that the **Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act (ANCSA)** is the **only statute** the ISDA’s “Indian tribe” definition mentions by name, thus **eligibility for ANCSA’s benefits satisfies the definition’s final “recognized-as-eligible” clause**.

Pair.Question: Which title of the CARES Act contained the funding for "Indian Tribes," and what was the Department of the Treasury's initial conclusion regarding the eligibility of ANCs for these funds?
Pair.Answer: Title **V** of the CARES Act makes funds available to "Indian Tribe[s]". The Department of the Treasury concluded that **ANCs were eligible** to receive Title V funds.

Pair.Question: What types of corporations did the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act (ANCSA) of 1971 authorize for the purpose of receiving money and land?
Pair.Answer: ANCSA authorized the creation of two types of corporations: **Alaska Native Regional Corporations** and **Alaska Native Village Corporations** (collectively ANCs).

Pair.Question: What specific concession did the government make regarding the historical recognition of ANCs, despite arguing for their inclusion in the ISDA definition?
Pair.Answer: The government conceded that ANCs have **not been historically recognized** as eligible for special programs and services because of their status as Indians.

Pair.Question: What was the reasoning provided by the District Court when it initially ruled in favor of the ANCs in this dispute?
Pair.Answer: The district court found that ANCs **must qualify as Indian tribes** to give effect to their **express inclusion in the ISDA definition**, even though no ANC has been recognized as an Indian tribe.

Pair.Question: What was the core reason cited by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit when it reversed the district court’s ruling?
Pair.Answer: The U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia reversed, holding that ANCs are **not eligible for funding** under Title V of the CARES Act because they are **not “recognized” as Indian tribes**.

Pair.Question: What was Justice Gorsuch's primary textual argument in his dissent against the majority’s holding that ANCs are "Indian tribes" under ISDA?
Pair.Answer: Justice Gorsuch argued that the majority overlooked the critical statutory word **“recognized”** and that the plain language and construction of the ISDA suggest that ANCs are not “Indian tribes”.

Pair.Question: How many federally recognized tribes from Alaska and the lower 48 states challenged the Treasury Department’s determination, and what was the central nature of their argument?
Pair.Answer: Six tribes from Alaska and twelve tribes from the lower 48 states (a total of 18 tribes) challenged the determination. Their central argument was that ANCs are **not “Indian Tribes”** within the meaning of the CARES Act or ISDA.

Pair.Question: What was the final disposition of the case, including the identity of the winning party and the vote breakdown?
Pair.Answer: The Supreme Court ruled that Alaska Native Corporations are **“Indian tribe[s]”** and thus eligible for CARES Act Title V funding. The winning party was **Yellen** (representing the Treasury Department/ANCs), and the decision was a **5-4 majority**.
